summary: The New Zealand national cricket team, nicknamed the Black Caps, played their first Test in 1930 against England in Christchurch, becoming the fifth country to play Test cricket.

Eden Park is New Zealand's largest sports stadium, located in central Auckland, New Zealand. It is used primarily for cricket in summer.

facts.label: Beginnings of cricket in New Zealand

value.label: The first recorded game of cricket in New Zealand took place in Wellington in December 1842.
New Zealand played its first two internationals (not Tests) in 1904–05 against a star-studded Australia team
In 1927 New Zealant toured England. They played 26 first class matches, mostly against county sides.
New Zealand played its first matches against the West Indies in 1951–52, and Pakistan and India in 1955/56.
Martin James Guptill, is a New Zealand international cricketer who plays as an opening batsman. Guptill holds the current record for the highest individual score in Cricket World Cup matches.

value.label: Colin Munro is a South-African born New Zealand international cricketer. He is the first player to score three Twenty20 International centuries.

value.label: Kane Stuart Williamson (is a New Zealand international cricketer who is currently the captain of the New Zealand national team and Sunrisers Hyderabad in the Indian Premier League. He is considered as one of the best batsmen in the world.

image.license: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 2.0 Generic license.

value.label: Taylor is considered as one of the greatest batsmen to represent New Zealand and became the nation's highest ODI century maker in 2017, with his 17th ODI century.

image.license: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 2.0 Generic license.

value.label: New Zealand were hosts and semi finalists of the 1992 Cricket World Cup
New Zealand went through to the semifinals and placed 3rd overall.

The 2007 Cricket World Cup (officially known as ICC Cricket World Cup 2007) was the 9th edition of the Cricket World Cup tournament that took place in the West Indies from 13 March to 28 April 2007, using the sport's One Day International (ODI) format.
New Zealand was runner's up in the 2009 ICC Champions Trophy

The ICC Champions Trophy was a one day international (ODI) cricket tournament organised by the International Cricket Council (ICC), second in importance only to the Cricket World Cup. Its name was changed to the Champions Trophy in 2002.
New Zealand was Runners-up at the 2015 Cricket World Cup.
ANZ
